forumNotes.author: was_jaclaz
forumNotes.content:
Well, that video is a "simplified" example of a recovery partition. The point is that if the partition where the small OS and the image are residing is normally visible, it will be "botched" before or later by the technically impaired in-laws, so a slightly more sophisticated approach is needed. You actually do not "need" grub4dos for this. (though you can use it to this effect, in other words grub4dos can do almost anything, but for simple things, simpler approaches may be better). The "usual" way to do so is using a special MBR code. There are at least two Freewares available: [http://www.boot-land...p?showtopic=334](http://www.boot-land.net/forums/index.php?showtopic=334 "External link") [http://www.terabyteu...ee-software.htm](http://www.terabyteunlimited.com/downloads-free-software.htm "External link") Start reading these: [http://www.boot-land...?showtopic=8296](http://www.boot-land.net/forums/index.php?showtopic=8296 "External link") [http://www.boot-land...?showtopic=6893](http://www.boot-land.net/forums/index.php?showtopic=6893 "External link")
And these: [http://www.boot-land...?showtopic=8761](http://www.boot-land.net/forums/index.php?showtopic=8761 "External link") [http://www.terabyteu...icle.php?id=277](http://www.terabyteunlimited.com/kb/article.php?id=277 "External link") To get the idea. Once you have a more clear understanding of the things needed, we will talk of details, and I'll split this into a new thread. jaclaz

forumNotes.author: was_jaclaz
forumNotes.content:
Personally, I would use a complex method, something along the lines of this:  
[http://www.boot-land...?...ic=7138\&hl=](http://www.boot-land.net/forums/index.php?showtopic=7138&hl= "External link")  
but you need a simple one.  

As such, I would go with the Terabyte utility, and since they were so nice as to provide it for free, I would at least have a go with their Image:  
DOS and Linux:  
[http://www.terabyteu...age-for-dos.htm](http://www.terabyteunlimited.com/image-for-dos.htm "External link")  
or Windows:  
[http://www.terabyteu...for-windows.htm](http://www.terabyteunlimited.com/image-for-windows.htm "External link")  

Since it is considerably more complex to setup a PE of some kind than a basic DOS or Linux, I would use the first.  

If you want to go all the way with Freeware only, you can use the MBLDR approach as well, a pseudo-tutorial is here:  
[http://www.msfn.org/...4-page-105.html](http://www.msfn.org/board/hp-notebook-recovery-partition-could-not-found-t131620-pid-849594-page-105.html "External link")  

Then, you can pick your choice among the (hopefully) complete "catalog":  
[http://www.msfn.org/...f...99.html\&hl=](http://www.msfn.org/board/disk-imaging-software-t100299.html&hl= "External link")  

It is difficult to advise someone, everyone has his own like and like-not, and many things depend on your current knowledge/experience, learning how to build a PE (if you are a complete n00b at it) or to make a Linux based recovery system may be daunting, and it is all in all not worth the effort if the ONLY outcome would be a recovery system.  

The only thing I do recommend is a KISS approach.  

You have basic requirements, use a basic app, you don't need PXE or Network, but there are completely freeware suites that do have this added features and also the basic ones, that require very little effort to be set up, as an example, PING:  
[http://ping.windowsdream.com/](http://ping.windowsdream.com/ "External link")  
has proven to be fairly easy to setup, but nonetheless found to be working very well, at least with the more sophisticated approach of PXE restoring.  

jaclaz

forumNotes.author: Grumpy Old Techie
forumNotes.content:
Tousif said: 'But yesterday night while surfing internet I got this virus which is making my boot time from 3 min earlier to 15+min now. And whenever i boot or reboot my computer there is a clicking noise in the hard drive which wasn't there before .'  

Tousif... the clicking noise from your hard-disk is unlikely to be a virus-related item.   

More likely, it is the mechanism that holds the read heads, banging against the end-stop.   

To be blunt: Your hard-disk has almost certainly developed a mechanical fault and will probably  
soon stop working completely.   

Take whatever steps you can to backup your hard-disk NOW, because there is no telling when   
it will fail completely.   

Regards,   

Grumpy Old Techie.

forumNotes.author: was_jaclaz
forumNotes.content:
XP SP2 on a 2Gb machine (which should mean also a pretty "fastish" CPU) should boot in less than 1 minute, with 40 to 45 seconds ideal. The "original" three minutes are simply "wrong". The "actual" fifteen minurtes are simply "folly". :wink: There are ALL the clues that your hard disk is dying on you. ![:rolleyes:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/rolleyes.gif) My personal advice is: * switch that machine off, **NOW**. * remove the hard disk from the machine and put it in another surely working, virus-free machine as slave OR * get yourself another hard disk, BIGGER than the original one * install to the latter a minimal system OR * get yourself another hard disk, EQUAL in size or BIGGER than the original one * use a live OS, like a PE of some kind from CD/DVD THEN * image the "old" hard disk with a cloning app, since the disk appears defective, this is advised: [http://www.boot-land...?...ic=7783\&hl=](http://www.boot-land.net/forums/index.php?showtopic=7783&hl= "External link") * procure yourself yet another hard disk of suitable size * restore the image on the last harddisk * try booting from it on the "original" machine
The usual words in these cases are: DON'T PANIC (assume the above to be written in large, friendly letters) BUT you must understand that every day, hour, minute and even second that that hard disk is on and running XP on NTFS partitions the probabilities of salvaging its contents decrease a little bit. You may want to ask help to some friend a bit more "technically experienced", if you don't feel confident enough, or even ask to a professional service, but, again, NOT to scare you :wink:, but whatever decisions you may take, take it ***quickly*** . ![:D](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/biggrin.png) jaclaz

forumNotes.author: was_jaclaz
forumNotes.content:
> I found this post [http://www.boot-land...?showtopic=8761](http://www.boot-land.net/forums/index.php?showtopic=8761 "External link") very helpful but I couldn't boot up with my USB stick as per that method. Whenever i boot with my USB stick there is only a black screen with a cursor blinking forever. Well, that's an alltogether different problem. You simply used the "wrong" or "old" utility to create the bootable stick, most probably the "HP USB formatting utility" which in some cases produces an unbalanced CHS and LBA. Depending on which filesystem you used, there are different "fixes" for that, read here: [http://www.911cd.net...o...=21049\&st=8](http://www.911cd.net/forums//index.php?showtopic=21049&st=8 "External link") and here: [http://www.boot-land...?...=8528\&st=21](http://www.boot-land.net/forums/index.php?showtopic=8528&st=21 "External link")
But I would re-start from scratch, using one of the "new" utilities known to correct these problems, choose one from here: [http://www.boot-land...?showtopic=9460](http://www.boot-land.net/forums/index.php?showtopic=9460 "External link") :wink: jaclaz
